page.title: 06Changes in a life-time.
page.content: Mrs Coe has lived in Uffington for the past 52 years. When she arrived at Stamford a pony bus met her. The village shop, along the main road, had the only telephone in Uffington. Sometimes it took 30 minutes to get a connection. The shop had a great range of goods and bread was delivered daily. Villagers got water from a pump or stand pipe in the road. The present village hall, The Bertie Arms and one house have the only remaining thatched roofs. During the first world war the village hall was a tin hut near the Bertie Arms. It was also used for billeting soldiers. Then there were three church services a day. Uffington House was accidently burnt down in 1903 but the ballroom still stood and was used as a meeting place. Entertainment was gained through quizzes and concerts.
